name: 世界文學名著選讀
goals: Through the study of selected poems, students will be able to understand, examine, and develop a critical though on western poetics.
Through discussion and debate, the goal of the course is to improve students' literary knowledge, and let them investigate and evaluate a wide range of different poetic texts.
Understand and learn close-reading and text analysis methods.
Students will practice oral and written English with the aim to develop their field language skills and to be able to discuss and write a short essay.
syllabus:
1.Week 1 Introduction: Traditional and contemporary idea of “world literature”; the “literary canon” and “world literature”; general historical background.

  

Ancient Greece and Rome

2.Week 2 Lyrics and Epic from the ancient period: Homer (c. 8th century BC), Sappho (c. 630-c. 570 BC), Catullus (84-54 BC), Virgil (70-19 BC), selected poems and extracts.

  

Middle Ages

3.Week 3 High Middle Ages: Old Occitan lyric poetry, Dante Alighieri (1265-1321), Vita Nova and Francesco Petrarca (1304-1374), Canzoniere, selected poems.

4.Week 4 Dante Alighieri, Divina Commedia, Canto I, III, V, extracts.

5.Week 5 Early English Literature: Geoffrey Chaucer (c.1343-1400), Canterbury Tales, extracts.

  

6.Week 6 (10/10) 

  

7.Week 7 Mid-term

  

From the Renaissance to the Baroque

8.Week 8 Edmund Spencer (1552-1599), Amoretti, William Shakespeare (1564-1616), Sonnets, Selected poems.

9.Week 9 John Donne (1572-1631), Holy Sonnets, John Milton (1608-1674), Paradise Lost, extracts. 

  

Post Enlightenment Era: Neoclassicism, Romanticism and Realism

10.Week 10 “First generation” of English Romanticism: William Wordsworth (1770-1850) and S. T. Coleridge (1772-1834), Lyrical Ballads, selected poems.

11.Week 11 Romanticism and Neoclassicism in Europe: Lord Byron (1788-1824), Percy Bysshe Shelley (1792-1822), Ugo Foscolo (1778-1827) and Gérard de Nerval (1808-1855) selected poems. 

12.Week 12 Realism and Romanticism in American poetry: Walt Whitman (1819-1892) and Emily Dickinson (1830-1886), selected poems.

  

Les poètes maudits and Symbolisme 

13.Week 13 Charles Baudelaire (1821-1867), Paul Verlaine (1844-1896), and Stéphane Mallarmé (1842-1898), selected poems.

  

Early twentieth century

14.Futurism and Surrealism: Tommaso Marinetti (1876-1944), Guillaume Apollinaire (1880-1918), selected poems.

15.Poetry between World Wars: Edna St. Vincent Millay (1892-1950), Harriet Monroe and the magazine Poetry.

16.Imagism and modernist poetry: Hilda Doolittle (1886-1971), Ezra Pound (1885-1972) and T. S. Eliot (1888-1965), The Waste Land, selected poems and extract.

grading.note: Students are requested to prepare a brief oral presentation and analysis of two poems listed on moodle.

Mid-term report: Students will prepare a short presentation about the topic (mainly one poet and his/her works) they want to discuss in the final paper.

Final report: According to the topic chosen during the semester, students will write a short paper in English.
